THE UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA
University Extension Division
CHAPEL HILL
October 7, 1952
Mr. C2*aydon Aubidlus, Director
Radio Broadcasting Services
Manager, WUOA (FM)
Extension Division
University, Alabama
Dear Mr. Ansmus:
The contents of your letter were quite a surprise. I had no idea that Earl Wynn
was interested in another position and I’m quite sure the University would regret
to have him leave. Consequently, I shall keep the news confidential.
As you probably know. Radio started as an activity of the Extension Division.
Dr. Ralph W. McDonald, now President of Bowling Green State University, Ohio, was
Associate Director in charge of radio and public forum activities. Mr. Wynn who
at that time (1939-^2) was connected with the Department of Dramatic Art, served as
our part-time director of radio programs. He did a very satisfactory production job
and helped arrange a series of programs by the Carolina Playmakers that was broadcast
over a national network. After the war, he returned with many new ideas about the
whole field of communication. Largely through his efforts, the Department of Radio
was established and in September 19^5 the Communication Center of the Consolidated
University of North Carolina was approved by the Board of Trustees. My Wynn was
appointed Chairman of the Department, Professor of Radio and Communication, and
Director of the Center.
My evaluation of Mr. Wynn is based upon contacts with him as Director of the Division,
Chairman of the Communication Committee of the faculty and as Chairman of the
Advisory Board of the Communication Center. The budget of the Center is listed
separately under the Extension section of the University’s budget and the Center is
considered one of the cooperative services of the Division. I have found him to be
a man of ideas, tact, and initiative. He has many friends throughout the country
and has been invited to serve on impesfcant national committees interested in educational
broadcasting. He has developed excellent working relationships with the N. C. Associa¬
tion of Broadcasters which co-sponsors the annual N. C. High School Radio Institute,
in cooperation with the Extension Division.
To be perfectly frank, as you requested, I must report that two or three personnel
problems have arisen during Mr. Wynn's administration. They involed questions of
academic tenure as well as professional efficiency. I believe he has learned a lesson
the hard way and that from now on he will be more careful both in the selection,
assignment, and treatment of staff members. In my judgment, most of the difficulties
were those of adjustment peculiar to a University organization. The staff of approxi¬
mately twenty persons is now working together very smoothly, effectively, and with v
excellent morale. I believe that most of these problems may be charged up to the
fact he has been building new agencies within the framework of a State University
